To answer your question, we need to understand first what “futuristic technologies” actually are. After all, any new technology could be described as “futuristic”! My definition for “futuristic” is that the technology changes the fabric of society in such a way that when future generations look back into the past, they can’t understand how people lived and existed without that technology. The entire world has changed and fit itself around the new technology. Technologies that fit this criteria from the past would probably surprise you, since they seem so ordinary to us now. And yet, for the people living in the times they were invented and used, they seemed like magic - just like flying and autonomous cars, or general artificial intelligence, seem to us. A surprising example for a technology from the past that fit this criteria is aluminum production. Aluminum used to be one of the rarest and most expensive metals on Earth. Napoleon III used to serve his most prestigous guests food on plates made of aluminum. Then, towards the end of the 19th century, a new production method for aluminum was discovered, and the metal became ubiquitous and cheap within two decades. Today, aluminum exists everywhere: in your car, bag, oven, refrigerator, and many other devices. For people living in the 19th century, this would’ve looked like science fiction - you’re enjoying riches that not even the wealthiest of kings had in those times. Now, if I had to guess about the future (which I am lucky enough to be doing for a living pretty much every day), I would put my money on artificial intelligence (AI). It’s already creeping into our lives everywhere: deciphering what you say to your digital assistants like Siri, Amazon Echo, Google Assistant and others; driving your Tesla car; making breakthroughs in science, and so on. My son is already talking with our Amazon Echo as if ‘she’ were a human being. He is going to grow up in a world in which everyone talks to machines all the time - and nobody would understand how people could live their lives before the machines could understand their words and even talk back.

If you want a physical entity you can point to as a “single piece of technology”, how about a state of the art mobile phone? Again, if you judge “advanced” by what would make your grandparents’ eyes pop out of their heads if they saw it 50 years ago, how about a pocket sized slab of metal, glass and plastic that lets you make calls on the move to people around the globe, access a vast array of knowledge and services, perform calculations instantly that would at that time have taken a room-sized computer months, watch movies, listen to almost any song ever recorded, play games with close to photorealistic graphics, take an almost unlimited number photographs and videos (and share them instantly around the world), and answer questions on Quora?

If you are fresh new to VR development, I recommend you to first try out one of the platforms that require no coding and have very small learning curves, just to get an idea of what ‘developing VR content’ looks like at a high level. ENTiTi Creator — Augmented & Virtual Reality Content Creation Platform Insta VR — Make your VR apps in Minutes Viar 360 — Create and Publish interactive cinematic VR experiences These platform provide tool sets for businesses in various industries to produce simple but high-quality advertisement/product demo/design visualization/training materials in VR/AR forms. You are probably not able to build fancy interactive functionalities with these platforms(but definitely the most basic ones such as drag-and-drop) that a good VR game might require, but you can surely learn a lot on how to import/create 3D assets, how to mess with a 3D object within a virtual scene, and how to customize your project with desired functions. Professional VR development, such as building an VR app/software/web, can be breaking down into several parts that would likely be done by different groups of people with different specialities - user experience design (storytelling, environment &interaction design, etc.), artistic design (3D modeling, animation, etc.), interaction prototyping, database management, and many other indispensable supporting parts. As you may unlikely master all of them, I recommend you to do some more research on what a VR development pipeline is like and dive more into part(s) that you are interested in the most. Personally I think user experience design is the least technical part and requires an interdisciplinary thinking on psychology, management, and creativity, as well as rich knowledge on what other people have tried and ability to evaluate why those approaches worked or did't work in a critical way. Fortunately, there are lots of good resources on user experience design in VR/AR development online: check this out. As for artistic design, for most part there’s little to no difference to making a 3D animation/3D modeling, so if you had experience in these fields, it won’t be hard for you to advance into VR! In case that you don’t know much about 3D animation but are interested in learning about it to do VR development, I recommend checking blender out. To do interaction prototyping in VR, the base line is to master technical skills that are crucial to any kind of game development in general - OOP (object oriented programing) and making an efficient and easy-to-manage data abstractions. You should be able to handle several levels of abstraction (empirical, schematic, maths, algorithmic) before starting to code. But building a software in VR form adds many more challenges to interaction prototyping. Non-linear storytelling feature, need to respond to trackable equipments, and many other unique features of VR all requires the developers to make change to interaction logic flow in regular game development. As your product would likely involve multiple users and user generated contents, and thus, it’s always good to check out Unity’s manual on multiplayers and networking even before you start your first project, just to get an idea of what the final work should be like and technologies you need to learn about to manage your project effectively. To get a quick kick-off on VR development in general, check out our complete beginner guide to VR development. If you'd like to dip more into VR development/VR content creation, follow me, check my bio and feel free to ask 360/VR relevant questions!

The best ever technology that I think is the Biotechnology. Biotechnology is the use of living systems and organisms to develop or make products, or "any technological application that uses biological systems, living organisms or derivatives thereof, to make or modify products or processes for specific use" (UN Convention on Biological Diversity, Art. 2). Depending on the tools and applications, it often overlaps with the (related) fields of bioengineering, biomedical engineering, biomanufacturing, etc.For thousands of years, humankind has used biotechnology in agriculture, food production, and medicine.The term is largely believed to have been coined in 1919 by Hungarian engineer Károly Ereky. In the late 20th and early 21st century, biotechnology has expanded to include new and diverse sciences such as genomics, recombinant gene techniques, applied immunology, and development of pharmaceutical therapies and diagnostic tests.

Freeman Dyson wrote about Our Biotech Future in the New York Review of Books in 2007. One of his suggestions was that the development and trajectory of biotechnology could follow that of information technology. That is to say, moving from the domain of large research institutions and big corporations into the hands of the average person. Once that occurs, and more people become familiar with the technology and find ways to use it, to develop “apps” as it were, then biotechnology would move from from the little-known and the controversial into the common, mundane and everyday. He was suggesting that this shift will occur over the course of this century—not by tomorrow. It’s a while since I read the article, and I don’t want to misstate his arguments so you might want to read it yourself to see if you agree with him. I do think though that what can potentially be done in engineering biotech could be revolutionary, with far-reaching impacts. Our future might be in growing products, rather than in manufacturing them, for example. We could understand our microbiota in ways that would overturn much of our medical knowledge. We may be able to re-engineer ourselves, our children, and the world’s ecosystems. That’s a lot of ground to cover, and it isn’t going to happen fast, which may be what you had in mind.
